conclusion: To solve the problem, I will analyze the geometric configuration and forces acting on the logs. I will calculate the necessary forces and angles to determine the dynamic friction factor between the logs and the ground.

The image shows three logs, A, B, and C, stacked on a horizontal surface. Each log has a circular section with radius R. The centers of these circles form an isosceles triangle with angle ∠O1 = 120°. The logs are of uniform thickness and mass m each.
The angle between the lines connecting the centers of the circles, ∠AOB, is 60°.
The force of static friction (fs) is given by fs = μsN, where μs is the coefficient of static friction and N is the normal force.
The normal force N is equal to the weight of the log, N = mg, where m is the mass of the log and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
The maximum static friction is equal to the sliding friction, so fs = μkN, where μk is the coefficient of kinetic (sliding) friction.

premise: Equating the two expressions for friction, fs = μsN and fs = μkN.
The dynamic friction factor between the ground and the logs is the coefficient of kinetic friction, μk.
conclusion: The dynamic friction factor is the same as the coefficient of kinetic friction, which is 1/3.
